A bed frame is a piece of furniture which is used to position a mattress and bed base and may include a means of supporting a canopy.
A bed base is a piece of furniture which supports a mattress.
A framed bed is a piece of furniture which is composed of a mattress supported by a bed base and held in place by a bed frame.
A cabinet is a roughly cuboidal piece of furniture which is used to store miscellaneous items in compartments accessible through doors or drawers.
A cupboard is a cabinet which is used indoors to store household objects such as food, crockery, textiles and liquor, and to protect them from dust and dirt
A clock is an instrument which may indicate, keep, and/or co-ordinate time.

comments: This may be a paraffin or an oil lamp. It can potentially be filled by inference if we can express that any lamp with pressurised fuel in the lamp reservoir is a pressure lamp. See Issue #228.
definitions: A pressure lamp is a portable paraffin or oil lamp in which fuel is forced up into the mantle or burner by air pressure in the reservoir, which can be increased by pumping with a plunger.
A spring through which fresh water flows.

comments: Subclasses will be added by inference.
definitions: A motor vehicle is a vehicle which is propelled by an engine or motor and that does not operate on rails.
A truck is a motor vehicle which, as its primary funcion, transports cargo rather than human passangers.
A water truck is a truck which transports water.
A vehicle is a mobile machine which transports people or cargo.

A car is a wheeled motor vehicle used primarily for the transportation of human passengers. Most definitions of the term specify that cars are designed to run primarily on roads, to have seating for one to eight people, to typically have four wheels, and to be constructed principally for the transport of people rather than goods.

comments: NB: "[A cart]...is different from a dray or wagon, which is a heavy transport vehicle with four wheels and typically two or more horses, or a carriage, which is used exclusively for transporting humans...Over time, the term "cart" has come to mean nearly any small conveyance, from shopping carts to golf carts, without regard to number of wheels, load carried, or means of propulsion." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cart
definitions: A cart is a vehicle which has two wheels and is designed to transport human passengers or cargo.
An animal-drawn cart is a cart which is attached to one or more working or draught animals.

comments: Difficult to distinguish from "ships". Similar to mountains and hills. " In naval terms, a boat is a vessel small enough to be carried aboard another vessel (a ship). Another less restrictive definition is a vessel that can be lifted out of the water. Some definitions do not make a distinction in size, as bulk freighters 1,000 feet (300 m) long on the Great Lakes are called oreboats. For reasons of naval tradition, submarines are usually referred to as 'boats' rather than 'ships', regardless of their size and shape." - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boat
definitions: A boat is a watercraft of any size which is able to float or plane on water.
A motor boat is a boat which is propelled by a motor.
A motor is a machine designed to convert one or more forms of energy into mechanical energy.
A bus is a road vehicle designed to carry many passengers.

comments: Depth can be added with specifications of BFO:role for both the car and the human operator.
definitions: A taxicab is a car which may be hired, along with its operator, to transport passengers between locations of their choosing.

comments: Ships, boats, hovercraft and submarines are all considered watercraft. The term would normally imply some propulsive capability (whether by sail, oar or engine) and hence is distinct from a simple device that merely floats, such as a log raft. - Wikipedia
definitions: A watercraft is a vehicle which is able to travel on or through water.
A bicycle is a human-powered, pedal-driven, single-track vehicle, having two wheels attached to a frame, one behind the other.
A motorcycle is a two- or three-wheeled motor vehicle.
A scooter or motor scooter is a motorcycle with step-through frame and a platform for the rider's feet.
A lentic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, has very little to no directed flow.
A lotic water body is a water body in which the accumulated water, in its totality, is flowing.

comments: This class refers to strictly sealed enclosures such as Biosphere 2 (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biosphere_2), rather than vivaria which allow matter exchange with external environmental systems.
definitions: A closed ecological system is a vivarium which does not rely on matter exchange with any part outside the system.

A mesocosm is a vivarium that is embedded within a natural environment and is used to place a relatively small part of that environment under experimental control for the purposes of scientific investigation.
A microcosm is a vivarium within which a simple ecosystem is artificially established and used to simulate and predict the behaviour of natural ecosystems under controlled conditions.
A manufactured structure made of interspaced structural elements such as metal or wooden bars or wires held together such that they may be used to confine, contain, or protect something.
A drylot is an enclosure of limited size usually bare of vegetation and used for fattening livestock.
A feedlot is a plot of land on which livestock are fattened for market
A chonolith is an igneous rock intrusion of irregular shape with a demonstrable base, absent in other types of irregularly-shaped intrusions.
A landmass which is part of a planet.

has_related_synonyms: A liquid planetary surface is a planetary surface layer where a liquid material of a planet comes into contact with atmosphere or outer space.

comments: This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's crust would be an instance.
definitions: A planetary crust is the outermost solid shell of a rocky planet or natural satellite, which is chemically distinct from the underlying mantle.

A planetary structural layer is laminar part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density. Planetary layers have differing physicochemical properties and composition.
editor_notes: Label should be improved to match definition.

comments: This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's mantle would be an instance.
definitions: A planetary mantle is a planetary layer which is an interior part of a terrestrial planet or other rocky body large enough to have differentiation by density.

comments: "Not to be confused with planetary core in the core accretion theory, referring to a central accretionary body surrounded by a halo of dust and gas which serves to trap debris and increase the rate of accretion.." WIkipedia:Planetary_core. This class is meant to be applicable accross planets. Earth's core would be an instance. The "layer" aspect of cores may be problematic.
definitions: A planetary core is the innermost structural layer or layers of a planet. The core may be entirely liquid, entirely solid, or have both liquid and solid parts.

comments: Needs a general definition that holds for Earth as well as other planets.
Needs a general definition that holds for Earth as well as other planets.

definitions: A liquid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of liquid material.
A solid planetary core is a planetary core which is primarily composed of solid material.

comments: Earth's lithosphere includes the crust and uppermost mantle.
definitions: A lithosphere is the outermost shell of a terrestrial-type planet or natural satellite that is defined by its rigid mechanical properties.
An asthenosphere is a layer of a terrestrial-type planet or natural satellite which is highly viscous, mechanically weak, and ductilely deforming.

A trench is a type of excavation or depression in the ground that is generally deeper than it is wide (as opposed to a wider gully or ditch), and narrow compared to its length (as opposed to a simple hole).
A channel of a watercourse which contains a stream.
An ocean strait is a strait which connects two oceans.
A stream channel which contains a river.

A slum is a heavily populated urban informal settlement with substandard housing in which households lack any one of the following: access to improved water, access to improved sanitation, sufficient-living area, durability of housing, or security of tenure.
An undersea trough is a trough which is below a marine water body.

comments: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "dense" can be determined as needed. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.
definitions: A settlement with a high density of buildings and inhabitants.
editor_notes: See also: http://www.ecotope.org/anthromes/v1/guide/urban/12_dense_settlements/default.aspx

comments: "Intrusion" can refer to the solidified mass or the molten rock.
definitions: An igneous intrusion is a mass of rock and minerals formed when magma cools, solidifies, and undergoes fractional crystallisation without reaching the surface.
editor_notes: Subclasses of this class will be created by inference.

definitions: A cone that is composed of consolidated volcanic ash.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of open water generally have less than 25% cover of vegetation or soil. A specific threshold is not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of water in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
A geological fracture is any separation in a geologic formation, such as a joint or a fault that divides a mass of rock into two or more pieces.

comments: The relationship between faults and active plate boundaries must be further developed, as there is some overlap.
definitions: A geological fault is a planar fracture or discontinuity in a volume of rock, across which there has been significant displacement as a result of rock mass movement.

An active fault is a fault that is likely to become the source of another earthquake sometime in the future. Geologists commonly consider faults to be active if there has been movement observed or evidence of seismic activity during the last 10,000 years.
A vein is a geological fracture which is filled with minerals precipitated out of an aqueous solution.
A sheet of rock that formed in a fracture in a pre-existing rock body.
A joint is a geological fracture which has no measureable shear displacement

comments: Sounds like this should be populated by inference.
definitions: A geological fracture across which shear displacement has occurred

A microfracture is a small fracture which is found in a portion of solid material along which further fracturing tends to occur. Microfractures are considered imperfections which to pre-exist any fractures formed by the application of stress to a material.

comments: Once defined, an atmospheric column can be used to quantify an atmospheric parameter such as pressure, ozone or precipitable water.
definitions: A fiat part of an atmosphere which is defined as a vertical, three-dimensional pillar extending from a unit area on a planetary surface and bounded by the top of the atmosphere.
A lake which has concentrations of environmental contaminants high enough to harm the ecosystems associated with it.
A mass of water.
A mass of marine water.

comments: Used for both marine and lake coasts. The boundary of the coast is fuzzy and it overlaps both the water body and land in quesiton. Compared to 'shore'
definitions: A coast is the area where land meets the sea, ocean, or lake.

comments: Usually reserved for large lakes.
definitions: The general region of indefinite width that extends from a lake inland to the first major change in terrain features.
An unusual accumulation of water above the ground caused by high tide, heavy rain, melting snow or rapid runoff from paved areas.

A coastal flood is a flood which is formed as a result of large amounts of water from marine water bodies or large lakes being transported to usually dry land by displacement processes such as high winds or seismic activity.
A riverine flood is a flood which is formed as a result of a river's flow rate exceeding the capacity of its channel.

A flash flood is a flood formed by the rapid flooding of geomorphic low-lying areas. It may be caused by heavy rain associated with a severe thunderstorm, hurricane, tropical storm, or meltwater from ice or snow flowing over ice sheets or snowfields. Flash floods may also occur after the collapse of a natural ice or debris dam, or a human structure such as a man-made dam. Flash floods are distinguished from a regular flood by a timescale of less than six hours.

A storm surge is a coastal flood which is caused by low-pressure weather systems such as tropical cyclones and strong extratropical cyclones, the severity of which is affected by the shallowness and orientation of the water body relative to storm path, and the timing of tides.
editor_notes: Needs links to weather when these phenomena are added.

definitions: A mass of igneous rock formed when hot magma flows out (extrudes) onto a planetary surface as lava or explodes violently into the atmosphere to fall back as pyroclastics or tuff.
A dike formed when sediment fills a pre-existing fracture in a mass of rock.
A stock is a discordant igneous intrusion having a surface exposure of less than 100 square kilometres. Stocks differ from batholiths only in being smaller.
editor_notes: Some assertion to indicate that stocks are smaller than batholiths should be made.

definitions: A sheet intrusion (or concordant pluton) that has been injected between two layers of sedimentary rock. The pressure of the magma is high enough that the overlying strata are forced upward, giving the laccolith a dome or mushroom-like form with a generally planar base.
A large igneous intrusion which is lenticular in shape with a depressed central region.

A phacolith is an intrusion parallel to the bedding plane or foliation of folded country rock. More specifically, it is a typically lens-shaped intrusion that occupies either the crest of an anticline or the trough of a syncline.
A tabular sheet intrusion that has intruded between older layers of sedimentary rock, beds of volcanic lava or tuff, or along the direction of foliation in metamorphic rock.

comments: A habitat's specificity to an ecological population differentiates it from other environment classes.
definitions: An environmental system which can sustain and allow the growth of an ecological population.

comments: This class covers part of the NLCD "Perennial Ice/Snow" class.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of water ice, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.

A self-contained constructed feature used by one or more households as a home, such as a house, apartment, mobile home, houseboat or other 'substantial' structure. A dwelling typically includes nearby outbuildings, sheds etc. within the curtilage of the property, excluding any 'open fields beyond'. It has significance in relation to search and seizure, conveyancing of real property, burglary, trespass, and land use planning.
editor_notes: Subclasses will be added by inference., See https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/issues/264 for discussion. This definition needs a lot of clean up and links to household and related classes must be made to form logical definitions for inference to work.

comments: This class covers part of the NLCD "Perennial Ice/Snow" class.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of snow, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, these areas are characterised by ice and/or snow cover generally greater than 25% of total cover. The definition of perennial needs clarification.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of snow or water ice, present throughout multiple years, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
labels: area of perennial ice or snow

comments: Regolith typically includes dust, soil, broken rock, and similar materials, but can be highly variable.
definitions: A solid layer which is composed primarily of loose, heterogeneous, superficial material covering solid rock.
editor_notes: The various parts of the regolith are highly variable. Perhaps some sort of "unconsolidated" quality should be used here with "environmental material" to cover this scope. Note that organisms, their parts, or their derivatives are also included.

comments: On Earth, all continental crust ultimately derives from the fractional differentiation of oceanic crust over many eons.
definitions: A layer of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks that forms continents and the areas of shallow seabed close to their shores, known as continental shelves.
editor_notes: This is an Earth-centred class, but can be generalised to include other planetary bodies.

definitions: Oceanic crust is the uppermost layer of the oceanic portion of a tectonic plate.
The Mohorovicic discontinuity, usually referred to as the Moho, is the boundary between the Earth's crust and the mantle, indicating a change in composition.
editor_notes: This is and Earth-centred definition, but can likely be applied to other differentiated planetary bodies.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of barren land generally have less than 15% cover of vegetation. A specific threshold is not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily composed of bedrock, desert pavement, scarp rock, talus, material exposed by slides, volcanic material, glacial debris, sand, material exposed during strip mining, gravel, and other accumulations of earthen material in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: The range of entities that are considered "barren land" are not exhaustive, making axiomatisation risky at this stage.

definitions: A hollow tower of ice formed by the freezing of steam escaping a fumarole.

comments: Similar, in spirit, to landform. This class may need to be split into aerosols and 'pure' volumes of gas.
definitions: A part of an astronomical body which is primarily composed of a continuous volume of gaseous or aerosolised material held in shape by one or more environmental processes.
editor_notes: This may not need to be in the atmosphere, also note that "meteor" will do much of the same work.

comments: The thresholds for what makes a settlment "sparsely populated" can be determined as needed. These are usually "sparse" in relation to urban environments. If there is a specific threshold that should be added to ENVO, please make a new class request.
definitions: A settlement with a low density of buildings and inhabitants.

comments: A class created fro SDGIO. The definition of rural is highly varied, dealing with areas, settlements, and populations interchangeably. The 'rural' classes in ENVO aim to clarify these differing definitions. See issue #272.
definitions: A settlement which has lower population density than a town, city, or other urban environment and is primarily used for agricultural or pastoral activity.
A settlement which has been established and is managed through officially sanctioned processes and is recognised as legal by a competent authority.
editor_notes: This is merely a defined class and should not have too many subclasses.

comments: Informal settlements need not be illegal.
definitions: A settlement which is not associated with or directed by official planning processes and which typically lacks municipal services and infrastructure such as sanitation, water services, and waste management services.
editor_notes: This is merely a defined class and should not have too many subclasses., Can a formerly formal settlement become an informal settlement?

definitions: A settlement on land that the inhabitants have a legal claim to.
editor_notes: This is merely a defined class and should not have too many subclasses.

definitions: A settlement on land that the inhabitants have no legal claim to or occupy illegally.
editor_notes: This is merely a defined class and should not have too many subclasses.

definitions: Forest which originally covered a region before changes in the environment brought about by people. (Source: PHC)

comments: Created for SDGIO, indicator 9.1.1. See #272.
definitions: A road which is usable across all seasons.

comments: A class created fro SDGIO. The definition of rural is highly varied, dealing with areas, settlements, and populations interchangeably. The 'rural' classes in ENVO aim to clarify these differing definitions. See issue #272.
definitions: An area which is outside of a town, city, or urban area. Rural areas are primarily used for agriculture or pastoralism and may contain rural settlements.

A village is a clustered human settlement or community, larger than a hamlet but smaller than a town, with a population ranging from a few hundred to a few thousand. Though often located in rural areas, the term urban village is also applied to certain urban neighbourhoods. Villages are normally permanent, with fixed dwellings; however, transient villages can occur. Further, the dwellings of a village are fairly close to one another, not scattered broadly over the landscape, as a dispersed settlement.
editor_notes: This class may be split. "urban village" doesn't sit well and prevents relations to village biomes.

definitions: A lake which has nutrient-poor water.
editor_notes: See issue #282

comments: What constitutes a "medium" nutrient level is subject to debate. The thresholds should be set either on a data level or through new subclasses.
definitions: A lake with medium nutrient levels, which allow moderate productivity.
editor_notes: See Issue #281.

comments: The selection process which determines the whether an area is an important site must follow the best practice specifications and guidelines developed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), using globally standardised criteria and thresholds. Note that the label 'important site' is chosen to align with SDGIO. The definition is that of "key biodiversity area".
definitions: An environmental zone which contains, as determined by an officially mandated selection process, one or more ecosystems which include, as parts, ecological communities of global significance for conservation due to their vulnerability and irreplaceability.
editor_notes: The narrow synonyms will be made into subclasses in their own right.
has_narrow_synonyms: Alliance for Zero Extinction Sites, Ecologically and Biologically Significant Area, IUCN Important Site for Freshwater Biodiversity, Important Bird Area, Important Mammal Area, Important Plant Area, Important Site for Freshwater Biodiversity, Prime Butterfly Area, Ramsar Sites

comments: We label this as 'public infrastructure', as the OECD definition refers specifically to public constructed features. The parts of public infrastructure are not exhaustive and should be extended as needed.
definitions: The system of public works in a country, state or region, including roads, utility lines and public buildings.
A road which is publically accessible.
editor_notes: This class is created for the SDGIO and the 'public infrastructure' class. The publically accessible attribute could be axiomatised.

definitions: A building which is publically accessible.
editor_notes: Created for SDGIO, we treat "public" as "publically accessible" where the semantics of access are dealt with in SDGIO.

definitions: A cable used to trasmit electricity from its point of production to its point of consumption.

comments: Created for SDGIO, we treat "public" as "publically accessible" where the semantics of access are dealt with in SDGIO.
definitions: A utility line which services the public power grid.

comments: Informal settlements may be urban or rural.
definitions: A populated place where groups of housing units have been constructed on land that the occupants have no legal claim to, or occupy illegally, or where dwellings are not in compliance with current planning and building regulations.
An atmosphere which surrounds a planet.

comments: An instance of this class would be Earth's atmosphere.
definitions: A planetary atmosphere which is composted primarily of dinitrogen and dioxygen gas.
A desert surface covered with closely packed, interlocking angular or rounded rock fragments of pebble and cobble size.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of deciduous forest are dominated by trees generally greater than 5 meters tall, and making up more than 20% of total vegetation cover. The NLCD 2011 continues to state that more than 75% of these trees should shed foliage simultaneously in response to seasonal change. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by a forest in which the majority of trees shed foliage simultaneously in response to seasonal change. The surfaces of this area (including the surface of the forest canopy) are in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.

comments: The gravitational sphere of influence referenced in this class' definition is the Hill sphere: a region in which an object dominates the attraction of satellites despite gravitational perturbations.
definitions: An astronomical body part which includes all the living entities within the gravitational sphere of influence of that body, as well as the non-living and dead entities with which they interact.
editor_notes: Whether this class should be grouped with classes such as "hydrosphere" and "cryosphere" requires some discussion.

comments: This is a very broad and, in practice, poorly defined term. Please consider using or requesting a more specific class.
definitions: An astronomical body part which is composed of the combined mass of water found on, under, and over the surface of a planet.

comments: This is a very broad and, in practice, poorly defined term. Please consider using or requesting a more specific class.
definitions: An astronomical body part which is composed of soil, subject to soil formation processes, and found on the surface of a lithosphere.
An astronomical body part which is composed of those parts of a star, distal from the star's core, from which light is radiated into space.

comments: In some literature, the term photosphere is used; however, this is more correctly reserved for a part of a star.
definitions: A planetary part which is exposed, at least periodically, to light.
An astronomical body part which includes those parts of a biosphere that are, at least periodically, illuminated and in which photosynthesis may occur.
editor_notes: Somewhat awkward at the moment, see #314.

definitions: A lake from which water constantly flows out of under almost all climatic circumstances, maintaining low concentrations of dissolved solid relative to endorheic lakes.

comments: The primary function of the eaves is to keep rain water off the walls and to prevent the ingress of water at the junction where the roof meets the wall. The secondary function is to control solar penetration; the eaves overhang can be designed to adjust the building's solar heat gain to suit the local climate, the latitude and orientation of the building, refer to passive solar building design. The eaves overhang may also shelter openings to ventilate the roof space.
definitions: A part of a building roof which overhangs the face of a wall and, normally, projects beyond the side of a building.
Overhanging eaves where the rafters and underside of the roof are visible from below.
Eaves in which projecting roof members are not visible, being closed from view by boarding.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of evergreen forest are dominated by trees generally greater than 5 meters tall, and making up more than 20% of total vegetation cover. The NLCD 2011 continues to state that more than 75% of these trees should maintain their foliage despite seasonal change - the canopy is never without green foliage. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by a forest in which the majority of trees maintain their foliage despite seasonal change. The surfaces of this area (including the surface of the forest canopy) are in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.

comments: Flower strips are often the last refuge organsims whose habitats have been replaced by croplands, urban areas, and othe anthropogenic environments. This has considerable consequences for pollination and other ecosystem services.
definitions: A vegetated area which includes a community of flowering plants that provide food for local pollinators.
editor_notes: This may or may not be an anthropogenic environment, but its boundaries are maintained by human activity.

comments: Flower strips are often the last refuge organsims whose habitats have been replaced by croplands, urban areas, and othe anthropogenic environments. This has considerable consequences for pollination and other ecosystem services.
definitions: A flower strip which is present at the margins of cultivated fields.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of mixed forest are dominated by trees generally greater than 5 meters tall, and making up more than 20% of total vegetation cover. The NLCD 2011 continues to state that neither deciduous or evergreen trees make up more than 75% of the total tree cover. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by a forest in which the trees are a mixture between those that lose and retain their foliage despite seasonal change. The surfaces of this area (including the surface of the forest canopy) are in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of dwarf scrub are dominated by shrubs less than 20 centimeters tall with shrub canopy typically greater than 20% of total vegetation. This type is often co-associated with grasses, sedges, herbs, and non-vascular vegetation. The NLCD 2011 notes that this is intended as an Alaska only land cover. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is partly covered by shrubs with ground-hugging stems or low growth habit, in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: As noted in Wikipedia: "Because the criteria are matters of degree rather than of kind, the definition of a subshrub is not sharply distinguishable from that of a shrub"

definitions: A turbulent surface layer of a water body maintained by strong currents setting over submerged ridges or shoals or by winds opposing a current.
editor_notes: This should likely be a part of the surface layer rather than a subclass.

definitions: A structure which is built into the container of a water body which allows water to flow out of the container when the volume of the water contained exceeds that of its cavity.
A site at the terminus of a liquid conveyance conduit where the liquid carried is discharged into the sea or a river.
An electric power system is a network of electrical components used to supply, transfer and use electric power.

A photovoltaic system is a power system designed to supply usable solar power by means of photovoltaics. It consists of an arrangement of several components, including solar panels to absorb and convert sunlight into electricity, a solar inverter to change the electric current from DC to AC, as well as mounting, cabling and other electrical accessories to set up a working system.
A group of solar panels, typically belonging to the same photovoltaic system, arranged to maximise interception of solar radiation.
A solar panel array that is integrated into the power system of a human dwelling.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of scrub or shrub are dominated by shrubs; less than 5 meters tall with shrub canopy typically greater than 20% of total vegetation. This class includes true shrubs, young trees in an early successional stage or trees stunted from environmental conditions. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by a shrubs, young trees, or stunted trees.. The surfaces of this area are in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: As noted in Wikipedia: "Because the criteria are matters of degree rather than of kind, the definition of a subshrub is not sharply distinguishable from that of a shrub"

comments: This class refers only to puddles of water, see https://github.com/EnvironmentOntology/envo/issues/337
definitions: A puddle is a small accumulation of water, on a surface. It can form either by pooling in a depression on the surface, or by surface tension upon a flat surface.

comments: Consider using http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_0000967 as a super-class
definitions: A ballast tank is a compartment within a boat, ship or other floating structure that holds water, which is used as ballast to provide stability for a vessel.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of developed open space are dominated by vegetation such as lawn grasses and include large-lot single-family housing units, parks, golf courses. Further, it is asserted that "impervious surfaces", most likely referring to concrete and related substances, cover less than 20% of the area. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by cultivated or anthropically maintained vegetation planted for recreation, erosion control, or aesthetic purposes interspersed by constructed or manufactured objects and materials. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. This would be helped by more clear listings of entities included in this classification. However, the class is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of developed space under low intensity usage are dominated by vegetation such as lawn grasses and include collections of single-family housing units. Further, it is asserted that "impervious surfaces", most likely referring to concrete and related substances, cover between than 20 - 49% of the area. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by cultivated or anthropically maintained vegetation and by constructed or manufactured objects and materials covering up to approximately half its extent. Such areas are used for low intensity purposes such as accommodating collections of single-family residential units. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. This would be helped by more clear listings of entities included in this classification. However, the class is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.
labels: area of developed space with low usage intensity

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of developed space under medium intensity usage are dominated by vegetation such as lawn grasses and include collections of single-family housing units. Further, it is asserted that "impervious surfaces", most likely referring to concrete and related substances, cover between than 50 - 79% of the area. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by constructed or manufactured objects and materials covering from half to three-forths of its extent and by cultivated or anthropically maintained vegetation. Such areas are used for medium intensity purposes such as accommodating dense collections of single-family residential units. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. This would be helped by more clear listings of entities included in this classification. However, the class is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.
labels: area of developed space with medium usage intensity

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, areas of developed space under high intensity usage are dominated by constructed features where humans reside and work.  Examples include apartment complexes, row houses and commercial/industrial facilities. Further, it is asserted that "impervious surfaces", most likely referring to concrete and related substances, cover between than 80 - 100% of the area. Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of developed space used for high intensity purposes such as accommodating dense and multi-occupant residential, commercial, and industrial units. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. This would be helped by more clear listings of entities included in this classification. However, the class is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.
labels: area of developed space with high usage intensity

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 80% of these areas are covered by sedge or forbs.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition. The NLCD description also notes that land covered by sedge tundra and sedge tussock tundra are subsumed in this category. The original definition notes that this is intended as an "Alaska only" category.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by sedges or forbs, possibly interpersed with grasses or grass-like plants. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.
labels: area of sedge- and forb-dominated herbaceous vegetation

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 80% of these areas are covered by grasslands or non-woody, herbaceous plants.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition. The NLCD description also notes that, while no "intensive" management such as tilling is performed in these areas, they may be used for grazing.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by gramanoid or herbaceous vegetation and which is not subject to intensive management by humans. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.
labels: area of gramanoid or herbaceous vegetation

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 80% of these areas are covered by lichens.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition. The original definition notes that this is intended as an "Alaska only" category.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by fruticose or foliose lichens and which is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 80% of these areas are covered by mosses.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition. The original definition notes that this is intended as an "Alaska only" category.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by mosses and which is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 20% of these areas are covered by pasturelands or hayfields.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition. The NLCD also notes that the crops are grown on a perennial cycle in these areas.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is partly covered by planted grasses, legumes, or mixtures of grass and legumes and used for livestock grazing or the production of seed or hay crops. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 20% of these areas are covered by croplands or actively tilled land.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition. The NLCD provides corn, soybeans, vegetables, tobacco, and cotton as examples of annual crops and the trees and vines in orchards and vineyards as examples of perennial woody crops.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is partly covered either by annual crops and perennial woody crops or by actively tilled land. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 20% of these areas are covered by forest or shrubland vegetation.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is partly covered by forest or shrubland vegetation and where the underlying soil or substrate is periodically saturated with or covered by water. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.

comments: According to the NLCD 2011, at least 80% of these areas are covered by herbaceous vegetation.  Such thresholds - which are themselves fuzzy - are not strictly asserted in this definition.
definitions: An area of a planet's surface which is primarily covered by perennial herbaceous vegetation and where the underlying soil or substrate is periodically saturated with or covered by water. This area is in contact with an atmospheric column extending from the planetary boundary layer to the planet's exosphere with little to no physical obstruction.
editor_notes: This class is in need of refinement, particularly in linking to other entities in the ontology. However, it is suitable for use in annotating remotely sensed land types.

comments: "Shrimp" is a common language term that may refer to multiple crustacean species, typically in the groups Caridea or Dendrobranchiatamarine. These may be marine or freshwater organisms.
definitions: A lentic water body which is used for the artificial culture of shrimp.
editor_notes: There are multiple subclasses possible for this term, including ponds managed by the traditional (extensive), improved traditional (semi-intensive), and intensive methods of cultivation.

comments: Feasting pits had a wide variety of social functions throughout time, which extended in scope from the single family group to multiple tribes or villages.
definitions: An archeological site which contains holes humans had dug in the ground, or their remnants, for the purpose of storing and distributing food, drink, and both functional or ritualistic implements during communal eating and drinking.

comments: A key example is the Boiling River, or Shanay-timpishka, of the Peruvian Amazon. This river is of high cultural significance and is protected by the shaman of the small town Mayantuyacu, a secluded healing center.
definitions: A river which is heated by geothermal processes such as heat exchange with lava or hydrothermal percolation.
A surface layer of a solid environmental material which is formed by the presence and activity of photosynthetic microbial assemblages colonising it.

comments: Couradeau et al. (2016) assert that any albedo reductions associated with biocrust development are due largely to the accumulation of the microbial sunscreen, scytonemin.
definitions: A biocrust which is formed by photosynthetic microbial assemblages colonising the surface layer of a portion of arid soil. Through their successional dynamics, these communities reduce the soil surface's albedo, impart it with stability against erosion, modify its hydrology, and promote its fertility.
has_exact_synonyms: biological soil crust, cryptobiotic soil, cryptogamic soil, microbiotic soil, microphytic soil, soil biological crust

definitions: An electronic telecommunications device that enables the customers of a financial institution to perform financial transactions, particularly cash withdrawal, without the need for a human cashier, clerk or bank teller.
has_exact_synonyms: automated banking machine, automatic teller machine, automatic telling machine, bankomat, cash machine, cashline, cashpoint, minibank

definitions: An environmental zone which overlaps a glacier or an ice sheet, and in which ice loss exceeds ice gain.
An animal house which is only partially surrounded by a building envelope.
An animal house which has a complete building envelope.
A manufactured cage which may be used to confine, contain, or protect an animal.

comments: Petting zoos are often nested within a zoological garden featuring wild non-human animals, not docile enough for humans to touch.
definitions: A petting zoo is a zoological garden which contains domesticated non-human animals and some wild non-human animals that are docile enough for humans to touch and feed.

An artificial channel which transports unwanted water or waste liquids away from their source, either to a more useful area, a receptacle, or into sewers or stormwater mains as waste discharge to be released or processed.
A facility in which non-human animals are slaughtered and processed for human consumption.

comments: Animals killed in knacker's yards are not fit for human consumption or can no longer be used to perform work.
definitions: A facility in which non-human animals are slaughtered and processed, but not for human consumption.

comments: This is a kind of day care facility. A facility need not be a building.
definitions: A building which is used to care for a human child during the working day by a person, outside the child's immediate family, other than that child's legal guardians.

comments: This is a kind of fish processing facility. Facilities need not be buildings, factory ships may be considered fish processing facilities.
definitions: A building in which fish are subject to a series of operations to prepare them for human consumption.

comments: An environment determined by the presence of a mushroom.

Ecological corridors may or may not provide habitats for the organisms which move through them. They serve to mitigate the effects of habitat fragmentation by allowing genetic exchange between populations that would otherwise be separated by, e.g., human activity.
definitions: An ecosystem which bridges two or more adjoining ecosystems and through which organisms may move or propagate.
has_related_synonyms: animal corridor, green corridor, habitat corridor, wildlife corridor

comments: This term refers to the ecosystem(s) the organisms traverse, rather than the spatial track they cover. The latter is better placed in a geospatial ontology.
definitions: An ecological corridor through which organisms move during a migration process.
editor_notes: Should be axiomatised with PCO's migration process once it is released.

definitions: A building in which nursing aides and skilled nurses provide care and treatment to residents who have significant difficulty coping with the required activities of daily living.
editor_notes: This class should be linked to SDGIO.
has_broad_synonyms: intermediate care facility, long-term care facility, old people's home, skilled nursing facility
has_exact_synonyms: care home, convalescent home, rest home

comments: This term is not to be used for hotels, hostels, inns and the like, which provides shorter-term stays.
definitions: A human house which serves as a long-term shelter for its inhabitants and within which they store personal property.
editor_notes: This is under "human house" due to the broad definition of "house".

definitions: A building within which food and drink are prepared and served to customers in exchange for money or other goods and/or services.
A part of an ecosystem which may be or has been used for one or more overnight stays by humans sheltering in tents, camper vans, caravans, or improvised shelters.
editor_notes: This is a very ambiguous term with wide-ranging usage patterns across cultural groups and regions.
has_exact_synonyms: camping ground, camping pitch, camping site, campsite

definitions: A campground which has been modified by humans to provide and maintain facilities for camping such as fire pits, road access, latrines, and garbage bins.
A campground which has no pre-existing facilities installed or maintained by humans, usually found outside of anthropised ecosystems.
A manufactured product which may hold a volume of heated water suitable for one or more humans to bathe in, usually for the purposes of hydrotherapy or pleasure.
Regions of a planet which are not exposed to the planet's atmosphere or space, often comprising parts of one or more planetary structural layers.
A region which overlaps parts of one or more planetary structural layers which are located below a continental landmass.
editor_notes: We may have to soften dependence on planetary structural layers as some planets haven't differentiated by density.

comments: This class will be axiomatised to coordinate with the 'vegetated area' class.
definitions: A hill which has a surface that is partially or wholly covered by plant communities.

comments: There are many subtypes of ecotone, some with sharp transitions and others with gradual, patchy transitions between communities. From Wikipedia:Ecotone - The word ecotone was coined from a combination of eco(logy) plus -tone, from the Greek tonos or tension  in other words, a place where ecologies are in tension.
definitions: An envirommental system which bridges two or more biomes and which includes ecological communities which blend these biomes' phylogenetic and phenotypic compositions.

comments:
Major vegetational ecotones such as that between the northern edge of the Boreal Forest in North America (or taiga in Russia) and the arctic tundra, known as the arctic tree-line ecotone, are controlled largely by large-scale airmass contrasts and are sensitive to climatic change, as noted by R. A. Bryson (1966).
Harvey Nichols, Ph.D. , April 23, 2017
Emeritus Professor of Biology.
definitions: An ecotone which bridges a subpolar coniferous forest biome and a tundra biome.
editor_notes: This assumes, of course, that the planet's or planetoid's poles receive less stellar radiation and/or thermal energy than equatorial regions.

definitions: A woodland which has an understory partially covered by lichen mats and tundra-like vegetation.

comments: In most contexts, 'natural' is defined by the lack of intervention or influence by humans and their activities. On Earth, most environments fall on a scale between completely natural and anthropised.
definitions: An environmental system in which minimal to no anthropisation has occurred and non-human agents are the primary determinants of the system's dynamics and composition.

An ecotone which overlaps at least one biome which supports the growth and persistence of trees and at least one that does not. Before ceasing altogether, tree growth becomes sparse and trees appear stunted as conditions become less favourable along this ecotone.
A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to the low temperatures or duration of snow cover that occur at increased elevations above mean sea level.
has_exact_synonyms: alpine tree line, alpine tree-line, alpine treeline

definitions: A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to insufficient water availability due to a lack of water-based precipitation.
has_exact_synonyms: desert tree line, desert tree-line, desert treeline

comments: The lack of rainfall in these ecotones is often due to their elevation above the condensation line of atmospheric water vapour.
definitions: A tree line ecotone across which trees cease to grow due to insufficient water availability caused by exposure to increased solar radiation and a lack of rainfall.
has_exact_synonyms: desert-alpine tree line, desert-alpine tree-line, desert-alpine treeline

comments: Mountain ranges isolated by oceans or deserts may have restricted repertoires of tree species and contain double tree lines.
definitions: A tree line ecotone which contains gaps in tree coverage due to decreased biodiversity in tree-forming plant species: gaps are above the alpine tree line for some species yet below the desert tree line for others, and no species with intermediate tolerances are present.
has_exact_synonyms: double tree line, double tree-line, double treeline

comments: Planets such as Jupiter and Saturn have primary atmospheres. Primary atmospheres are very thick compared to secondary atmospheres like the one found on Earth. The primary atmosphere was lost on the terrestrial planets due to a combination of surface temperature, mass of the atoms and escape velocity of the planet.
definitions: A planetary atmosphere which is formed as a result of the accretion of gaseous matter from the accretion disc of the planet's star.

comments: A secondary atmosphere is found on many terrestrial planets such as Mercury, Venus, and Mars. Secondary atmospheres are relatively thin compared to primary atmospheres like Jupiter's. Earth has a tertiary atmosphere due to biotic processes.
definitions: A planetary atmosphere which has formed as a result of its planet's volcanic activity, or by accumulation of material from comet impacts.

comments: Further processing of a secondary atmosphere, for example by the processes of biological life, can produce a tertiary atmosphere, such as that of Earth.
definitions: A planetary atmosphere which has formed as a result of biotic processes modifying a secondary atmosphere.
editor_notes: This definition cites biotic processes; however, the source indicated that other processes may cause a secondary atmosphere to transition into a tertiary one. More input is needed.

definitions: A construction which is designed to hold water in which humans may swim or perform other leisure activities.
has_exact_synonyms: paddling pool, swimming bath, swimming pool, wading pool

definitions: A constructed swimming pool which is owned by a non-governmental legal entity or a collective of such entities.
A constructed swimming pool which is owned by a governmental or state entity.

comments: Sources of water include rivers, lakes, reservoirs, and other water bodies. Conduits include canals, pipelines, and tunnels. Water intakes typically transport water for purposes of hydroelectric power engineering, water supply, or irrigation.
definitions: A hydraulic-engineering installation which transports water - in specified amounts, of a specified quality, and in accordance with a water-consumption plan - from a source of supply into a conduit.
A building which provides the site for food services with little or no waiting staff furnishing table service.

comments: The food products sold in a delicatessen are often considered unusual by the majority of its customers and may come from foreign food supplies which are not widely imported into its region of operation.
definitions: A food shop which sells a selection of food products that are not typical dietary components of the human population it is co-located with.

comments: Due to the facilities on board, food trucks are often larger than other trucks with comparable mechanics.
definitions: A truck which is equipped to cook and sell food.
A restaurant which provides prepared meals or other food products that the purchaser must eat off its premises.

comments: This definition of kiosk is characteristic of the Western hemisphere and used in English-speaking countries.
definitions: A booth with an open window on one side.
editor_notes: The relation between booths and buildings needs to be clarified. Booth should be its own class.

comments: This definition of kiosk is characteristic of the Western hemisphere and used in English-speaking countries.
definitions: A kiosk from which food products are sold.
editor_notes: The relation between booths and buildings needs to be clarified. Booth should be its own class.

definitions: A manufactured product which is designed to catch and hold animals.
An animal trap which consists of a container set flush with the ground such that animals moving along the ground may fall in and be available for examination or collection.
A pitfall trap in which a glass, plastic, or metal container devoid of accumulations of any liquid is used to contain any animal that falls inside.

comments: Aqueous solutions used in these traps include: formalin (10% formaldehyde), alcohol, methylated spirits, trisodium phosphate and picric acid.
definitions: A pitfall trap in which the container used to hold trapped animals is filled with a liquid solution formulated to hold, kill, and preserve any animal or animals which falls within it.
A channel of an intermittent stream which contains a river when water supply exceeds evapotranspiration and bed seepage.
A channel through which a directional flow of water periodically occurs, ceasing when bed seepage or evapotranspiration exceed the available water supply.

comments: The gravitational sphere of influence referenced in this class' definition is the Hill sphere: a region in which an object dominates the attraction of satellites despite gravitational perturbations.
definitions: A part of an astronomical body which includes, as parts, all the entities which have been constructed or manufactured by humans or their technology and which are within the gravitational sphere of influence of that body.
A food shop in which food products are the primary offer for sale or trade.

comments: Fairgrounds, or parts thereof, may be constructed (e.g. concreted over) or be natural (e.g. clearings or heaths), thus land use is the key differentia.
definitions: A part of an ecosystem which has been allocated to host a gathering of people for multiple entertainment or commercial activities.
editor_notes: A good candidate to draft land use semantics around

definitions: A fairground which is used to exhibit agricultural technology, livestock, and farm-related activity.

comments: As with campgrounds and fairgrounds, land use is the key differentia here. The regularity of marketplace activities may provide a differentia for further growth of this branch.
definitions: A part of an ecosystem where people gather for the purchase and sale of provisions, livestock, and other goods.
editor_notes: Hierarchies based on land use should replace the anthropogenic feature class once we have a stable rationale.
has_exact_synonyms: bazaar, marketplace, mercado, palengke, souk, tianguis

definitions: A food shop in which the food products on offer are restricted to those produced in a region and cultural setting other than that of the shop's locality.
has_exact_synonyms: ethnic food store, ethnic speciality shop, ethnic speciality store

definitions: An exchangeable device which can be connected to a plumbing system to deliver and drain water.
A plumbing fixture which is bowl-shaped and used for washing hands, dishwashing, and other purposes.

comments: Of course, there are other uses for bathtubs.
definitions: A plumbing fixture which may serve as a container for water in which humans or other animals may bathe.

comments: Indoors, there is a drain in the floor. Most showers have temperature, spray pressure and adjustable showerhead nozzle. Showering is common in Western culture due to the efficiency of using it compared with a bathtub. Its use in hygiene is, therefore, common practice. A shower uses less water on average than a bath: 80 litres for a shower compared with 150 litres for a bath.
definitions: A plumbing fixture within which a human or other animal may bathe under a spray of water.
editor_notes: As some showers have no drain, this may cause issues with the definition of plumbing fixture.

comments: See http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_01000979 for the channel of an intermittent river.
definitions: A dry stream channel through which a river had flowed, but now contains no appreciable accumulations of water.

comments: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation.
definitions: An environmental system which is determined by materials bearing roughly homogeneous qualities.
labels: environmental system determined by a quality

comments: Organisational class. Not intended for annotation. Subclasses describe environments which are usually permeated by an environmental material. They may also describe environments which are sufficiently close to a material, that their dynamics are strongly influenced by it (e.g. a patch of forest ecosystem neighbouring a uranium dump).
definitions: An environmental system within which an environmental material strongly influences the system's composition and properties.
labels: environmental system determined by a material

definitions: An environmental system determined by the presence of a plant rhizosphere.
An environmental system which is determined by a living organism.
labels: environmental system determined by an organism

definitions: An environmental system determined by a green plant.
An environmental system determined by an animal.

comments: This class (term) is defined by the lack of a quality (i.e. the lack of salinity or increased osmolarity), which is not best-practice ontologically. Use for annotation is generally discouraged and users should use classes which positively describe the material or environment sampled (i.e. stating the qualities the entity has, rather than those it does not).

definitions: A lake which is composed primarily of water with very high nutrient concentrations.
A lake which is primarily composed of water with a concentration of dissolved salts greater than that of ocean water.

comments: In response to historical misuse of the term in literature, these lakes are better referred to as "humic lakes". Although dystrophic lakes are often considered acidic and nutrient-poor (oligotrophic), these lakes actually vary greatly in terms of both pH and productivity. Due to the low pH associated with dystrophic lakes, few bacterial species and other aquatic life are able to survive. They are common in the taiga of North America and Eurasia.
definitions: A lake which is composed primarily water with high concentrations of humic substances and organic acids, resulting in brown- or tea-coloured colouration.
A lake which has formed as the result of processes that are not or are only minimally driven by human activity.
editor_notes: This class is to be filled by inference.

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by feces.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a bodily secretion of a metazoan.
labels: environment determined by a metazoan secretion

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a substance produced by a plant.
labels: environment determined by a plant substance

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a plant.
labels: environment determined by a biofilm on a plant surface

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a digestive tract.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a animal.
labels: environment determined by a biofilm on an animal surface

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on the surface of a fungus.
labels: environment determined by a biofilm on a fungal surface

comments: The thresholds for "significant" concentrations of salts vary widely and thus no committment is made in this class. Subclasses with more explicit thresholds can be made upon request.
definitions: An environment which is determined by materials which bear significant concentrations of salts.
An environmental system determined by a fungal structure.

comments: This term can be understood as a negative experimental control primarily composed of sterile water. The quantity of sterile water used may be contaminated; to express pure sterile water, please use http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/ENVO_00005791
definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sterile water.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by hypersaline water.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by soil.
A region which overlaps parts of one or more planetary structural layers which are located below an oceanic plate.
editor_notes: We may have to soften dependence on planetary structural layers as some planets haven't differentiated by density.

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by the subsurface zone of a planet.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by those parts of a planetary subsurface zone which are not saline.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment permeated by non-saline water.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by sediment permeated by saline water.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on a surface which is exposed to non-saline materials.
labels: environment determined by a biofilm on a non-saline surface

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by an aerosol.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a saline aerosol.
An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by an aerosol with a low concentration of dissolved solutes.
An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead animal, or a whole small animal.
labels: environment associated with an animal part or small animal

definitions: An environmental system which has its properties and dynamics determined by a biofilm on a surface which is exposed to saline materials.
labels: environment determined by a biofilm on a saline surface

definitions: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead plant, or a whole small plant.
labels: environment associated with a plant part or small plant

definitions: An environmental system determined by part of a living or dead fungus.
labels: environment associated with a fungal tissue

definitions: A lake which is contained within a caldera.

comments: Note that this class does not commit to what kind of crater contains the lake in question. Please see the subclasses for more specificity.
definitions: A lake contained within a crater.
A lake which is contained in a crater formed by a meteorite impact.
has_exact_synonyms: meteorite crater lake, meteorite impact crater lake

definitions: A lake which is contained in a crater formed by an impact event.
A crater which was formed as a result of the impact of one astronomical body on another.
A lake which is primarily composed of anoxic water.
A lake which has a hypolimnion composed primarily of anoxic water.
A lake which has a hypolimnion composed primarily of hypoxic water.
A lake which is primarily composed of hypoxic water.
A lake which is primarily composed of oxic water.
A lake which has a hypolimnion composed primarily of oxic water.
A lake which is contained in a depression formed by the deformation and resulting lateral and vertical movements of a lithosphere.
A part of a lithosphere which is separated by other such parts by geographic faults or similar geomorphological discontinuities.
A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates move towards, away from, or along one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere.
A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates are actively moving away from one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere that forms rifts or ridges.
has_exact_synonyms: constructive boundary, constructive plate boundary, divergent boundary, extensional boundary, extensional plate boundary

definitions: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates are actively moving towards one another, resulting in deformation of the lithosphere that forces one plate below the other where it melts in the mantle.
has_exact_synonyms: convergent boundary, destructive boundary, destructive plate boundary

definitions: A geomorphological feature which is formed where two or more tectonic plates are actively moving along one another in either a sinistral (left lateral) or dextral (right lateral) horizontal direction.
editor_notes: This class overlaps with the semantics of geographic faults and further work needs to be done to disentangle them.

definitions: A compound astronomical body part in which extensional tectonic processes occur and where the lithosphere is being pulled apart.
A lake which fills a basin that has been dammed by wind-blown sand,  formed between sand dunes oriented by winds; or formed by wind action under previously arid paleoenvironments.
A lake which fills a depression where drainage is blocked by solid material transported by a landslide.
A lake which fills a depression where drainage is blocked by solid material transported by a rockslide.

comments: These vortices are responsible for such phenomena as the "singing" of suspended telephone or power lines, and the vibration of a car antenna at certain speeds.
definitions: A succession of swirling vortices caused by the unsteady separation of flow of a fluid around one or more blunt bodies.
has_exact_synonyms: Krmn vortex street, von Krmn vortex street

comments: This class will be primarily filled by inference, any environmental system which necessarily includes living parts should be autoclassified here.
definitions: An environmental system which includes both living and non-living components.
A channel which was formed as a result of an annelid burrowing through soil, where organic residues lining the burrow have subsequently initiated fossilization.
A physical space, which may or may not be in a construction, which is used to store animal feed for agricultural purposes.
editor_notes: This should be moved to "zone", and inference should be used to link to agricultural feature.

definitions: A physical space, which may or may not be in a construction, which is used to store animal manure for agricultural purposes.
A product which is composed primarily of animal manure that has been heat treated and packaged as a product for commercial or consumer use.
A cloud which is cirriform and is formed by condensation events centred on an aircraft's contrail.

comments: When present in aggregates, individual cirrus clouds are organised in patches or narrow bands. When organised in sheets of fibres they can give a silky sheen. When well-illuminated by sunlight (excluding during sunrise and sunset) cirrus clouds appear white or mostly white. Absence of any precipitation.
definitions: A cloud which 1) has been shaped into detached fibrous filaments, 2) is almost exclusively composed of ice crystals, 3) is located in the high level of the atmosphere (high tage).
